Literature Review: The advent of genomic data has revolutionized our understanding of human evolutionary history, offering unprecedented insights into population relationships and demographic events. This literature review explores the methodologies employed in assessing population relationships and history through genomic data, focusing on demographic inference, admixture, ancestry, effective population size, and molecular clocks. The integration of large-scale datasets from diverse human populations, alongside advancements in computational techniques, has significantly enhanced our capacity to reconstruct the human past. One of the foundational approaches in this domain is the use of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and STRUCTURE-like algorithms to infer population structure and ancestry. These methods have been instrumental in identifying genetic clusters that correspond to geographic regions and in detecting admixture events between populations (Pritchard et al., 2000; Patterson et al., 2006). Demographic inference, another critical area, leverages coalescent theory and likelihood-based methods to estimate historical population sizes, migration rates, and divergence times. Studies utilizing these approaches have shed light on the complex demographic history of human populations, including the Out-of-Africa migration and subsequent population expansions (Gutenkunst et al., 2009; Schiffels & Durbin, 2014). The concept of effective population size (Ne) is pivotal in understanding genetic diversity and the impact of demographic changes on genetic variation. Methods to estimate Ne from genomic data have evolved from classical approaches based on linkage disequilibrium to more sophisticated models that account for population structure and selection (Hayes et al., 2003; Do et al., 2014). Molecular clocks, calibrated using known mutation rates, provide a temporal framework for evolutionary events. The application of molecular clocks to genomic data has enabled the dating of key events in human history, such as the divergence of modern humans from Neanderthals and Denisovans (Scally & Durbin, 2012). Despite these advancements, challenges remain, including the accurate modeling of complex demographic scenarios and the integration of genomic data with archaeological and linguistic evidence. Future directions in the field may involve the development of more robust statistical models, the incorporation of ancient DNA, and the exploration of epigenetic markers to gain deeper insights into human evolutionary history (Skoglund & Mathieson, 2018; Posth et al., 2018). In conclusion, genomic data, complemented by interdisciplinary approaches, continues to be a powerful tool in unraveling the intricate tapestry of human population relationships and history.
